head.title: Prostate Screening, For All Men at Risk

hedline.hl1: Prostate Screening, For All Men at Risk

abstract.p: Linda Logdberg letter comments on May 10 article on disclosure by New York City Police Comr Howard Safir that he has prostate cancer, days after similar disclosure by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani (S)

block.p: You report (news article, May 10) that Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced that he had prostate cancer, just a week and a half after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani learned that he had the disease. As a cancer survivor of nine years, I know that the waiting before a treatment plan is in place is the hardest time of all. In most cases, the therapy is not as bad as one thinks, and there are treatments for side effects.

You report (news article, May 10) that Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced that he had prostate cancer, just a week and a half after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani learned that he had the disease. As a cancer survivor of nine years, I know that the waiting before a treatment plan is in place is the hardest time of all. In most cases, the therapy is not as bad as one thinks, and there are treatments for side effects.

Both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Safir got a routine blood test that detected the cancer at an early stage, permitting treatment before the malignancy can spread. Do they realize that preventive health care is a luxury out of reach of the thousands of New Yorkers who lack a health care plan?

Emergency rooms, where most of the poor are treated, don't do such screening. As a powerful force in the city's health care drama, the mayor should make early detection a possibility for every at-risk man in New York City.
LINDA LOGDBERG Upper Nyack, N.Y., May 10, 2000
